metadata.title: Kidney Disease, Chronic
anatomical location body part affected: Kidneys/renal nephrons (i.e., glomeruli and tubules); renal blood vessels; heart; blood; multiple systemic comorbidities
description: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a common medical condition, affecting 11–13%  of U.S. adults aged 20 years and older, that is mainly due to uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes(9,10,27)
CKD is defined as a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) to below 60 ml/ min/1.73m2 (normal values range from 90 to 120 ml/min/1.73m2) for 3 months or more(27)

CKD can be broken down into the following stages:(27) –Stage 1 – Kidney damage with normal or elevated GFR (≥ 90) –Stage 2 – Kidney damage with mildly reduced GFR (60–89) –Stage 3a – Mildly-moderately  reduced GFR (45–59) –Stage 3b – Moderately-severely  reduced GFR (30–44) –Stage 4 – Severely reduced GFR (15–29) –Stage 5 – End-stage  renal disease – GFR < 15 (or on dialysis)

In most cases, the characteristic signs and symptoms of CKD do not appear until excessive metabolic toxins accumulate in blood (uremia), and thus the diagnosis is usually made at an advanced stage of renal impairment(27)
Physical functioning often is compromised after signs/symptoms of uremia appear, and worsens with disease progression(1)

Individualized aerobic and resistance exercise training is indicated to counteract cardiovascular deconditioning, muscle weakness, and increased coronary risk, as well as to improve functional capacity, uremia-specific  measures, and QOL(1)

Authors of a 2015 review recommended that prescription of exercise interventions should become part of the standard nephrological care for patients with CKD(28) –Based on the fact that physical activity (PA), cardiorespiratory fitness, and muscle function are low in patients with CKD and that a sedentary lifestyle has been associated with an increased risk of mortality and morbidity –An expert statement issued by researchers in the United Kingdom (British Association of Sport and Exercise Sciences – BASES) also states that renal medicine services need to evolve to incorporate exercise rehabilitation as part of a comprehensive and integrated renal care package, including “exercise on prescription”(29)

This Clinical Review discusses interventions in CKD patients in stages 1–4 who are not dependent on hemodialysis or kidney transplantation; i.e., interventions required to sustain life in ESRD  –Exercise prescription during dialysis treatments or after kidney transplantation is the focus of a separate review. (See Clinical Review…Renal Dialysis and Exercise ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709129)

ICD-10 codes.I12.0: hypertensive renal disease with renal failure (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, and not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Hypertension is the most common physical finding and is often present in early stages of CKD(27)

General symptoms of uremia usually do not present until CKD is advanced. They include(27) –persistent fatigue (lethargy) –anorexia –nausea and vomiting –metallic taste in the mouth –Irritability, memory impairment, insomnia, restless legs
Shortness of breath with minimal exertion
Edema (e.g.,swollen feet and ankles and puffiness around eyes)
Muscle atrophy Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Differential diagnosis is important as there are many reversible causes of kidney injury, including(29) –infection –obstruction –extracellular fluid volume depletion or significant hypotension relative to baseline –hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia –nephrotoxic agents –severe/urgent hypertension –heart failure
Stop the exam and notify physician if patient reports symptoms of cardiac insufficiency such as angina, inappropriate shortness of breath, dizziness, etc.

Stop exercise testing or exercise training at the onset of symptoms resulting from exertion. In the absence of symptom limitations, exercise should be terminated at voluntary fatigue or other predetermined endpoints specific for the patient’s tolerance(2)

causes: Primarily due to uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes but also associated with the following:–Glomerular diseases-Primary glomerular diseases-Focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis-Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis-IgA nephropathy-Membranous nephropathy-Hereditary nephritis-Secondary glomerular diseases-Diabetic nephropathy-Renal amyloidosis-Postinfectious glomerulonephritis-HIV-associated  nephropathy-Collagen-vascular  diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus)–Tubulointerstitial nephritis-Drug hypersensitivity-Heavy metals-Analgesic nephropathy-Reflux/chronic pyelonephritis-Sickle cell nephropathy-Idiopathic–Cystic disease-Polycystic kidney disease-Medullary cystic disease–Obstructive nephropathies-Prostate disease-Nephrolithiasis-Retroperitoneal fibrosis/tumor-Congenital–Vascular disorders-Hypertensive nephrosclerosis–Renal artery stenosis
pathogenesis: Causes mentioned above lead to destruction of nephrons, which leads to compensatory hypertrophy and hyperfiltration ofremaining nephrons. Compensatory hyperfiltration in remaining nephrons leads to overwork injury, causing progressiveglomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis(27)

Markers of impaired renal function include low GFR, azotemia (accumulation of nitrogenous toxins in blood, such as ureaand creatinine), passage of protein and albumin in urine, and retention of water, sodium, and potassium (leading to edema)

Complications from CKD occur at fairly predictable stages of disease(27)–Hypertension – present in all stages of the disease process–Increased levels of parathyroid hormone and anemia – usually occurs in stage 3a or 3b–Increased levels of phosphorus – early in stage 4–Acidosis and hyperkalemia as the patient approaches stage 5–Uremic syndrome in stage 5
risk factors: Traditional cardiovascular risk factors, especially smoking, hypertension, physical inactivity, and obesity
Dietary habits that promote weight gain, diabetes mellitus, or hyperlipidemia
Abuse of alcohol or illegal substances
Failure to implement medical screening and monitoring criteria for CKD in early stages(9,10)
History of HIV or hepatitis C virus infection (10)
Poor adherence to medical advice on CKD-related  risk factors
Blacks, Hispanics, Pacific Islanders, Native Americans, and older adults are at increased risk
Kidney donation does not increase risk of CKD later in life(27)

Hypertension during pregnancy(18)–The risk of developing CKD and ESRD was greater for women with hypertensive pregnancy disorders based on acohort study of 26,651women in Taiwan with hypertensive pregnancy disorders. The risk was greater in women withpre-eclampsia or eclampsia compared with those with gestational hypertension only

overall contraindications precautions: Notify physician if a patient presents with recent onset of signs and symptoms of acute illness, including unusual/atypical fatigue fever malaise flulike symptoms (e.g., chills, headache, dizziness, muscle aches) pulmonary crackles/rales increased nausea diarrhea
Start-up  workloads should feel “light” during either exercise testing or exercise training; allow the patient a warm-up  period to avoid overexertion

Postpone PA/exercise therapy and notify physician in case of(2) chest pain resting systolic blood pressure (BP) over 200 mmHg resting diastolic BP over 110 mmHg erratic, fluctuating, or inappropriate BP response severe headache, dizziness, or lightheadedness occurs during exercise prolonged fatigue after exercise

Between 1% and 4% of patients with CKD on hemodialysis develop calciphylaxis, a cutaneous ischemic infarct caused by occlusion of blood vessels in the dermis and subcutaneous fat. This is a severe disorder associated with a 40% to 80% mortality rate. Patients present with extreme pain, sudden skin lesions that most often occur on the lower extremities, and signs of infection or sepsis. Notify the referring physician immediately(16)
Contact sports should always be avoided to prevent trauma to the kidneys
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Differential diagnosis is important as there are many reversible causes of kidney injury, including(29) –infection –obstruction –extracellular fluid volume depletion or significant hypotension relative to baseline –hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia –nephrotoxic agents –severe/urgent hypertension –heart failure
Stop the exam and notify physician if patient reports symptoms of cardiac insufficiency such as angina, inappropriate shortness of breath, dizziness, etc.

Stop exercise testing or exercise training at the onset of symptoms resulting from exertion. In the absence of symptom limitations, exercise should be terminated at voluntary fatigue or other predetermined endpoints specific for the patient’s tolerance(2)

course of treatment.medical management: Is the patient being treated for cardiovascular disease (e.g., coronary artery disease, hypertension, heart failure, hyperlipidemia), diabetes, neurological disease, osteoporosis, or other comorbidities? Is the patient on dialysis?
course of treatment.medications: Certain medications (e.g., beta blockers, diuretics) might affect exercise heart rate (HR) or BP. Document these and confirm that they are being taken The American Academy of Physicians published clinical practice guidelines in 2013 based on a systematic review of(17) Patients with hypertension and stage 1 to 3 CKD should be prescribed an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an angiotensin IIreceptor blocker (ARB) Statin medications should be prescribed to manage elevated low-density  lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in patients with stage 13 CKD
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests:  The laboratory workup might include the following:
ECG  resting and exercise recordings might indicate heart disease (e.g., ischemia, arrhythmias, hypertrophy)

Biomarkers of impaired renal function (e.g., decreased serum albumin; increased white blood cell count; increased serum calcium and phosphate; increased urinary urea, creatinine, potassium, phosphate, and calcium)
Blood glucose (a high percentage of patients with CKD have diabetes)
Hematocrit, hemoglobin, red blood cell count (low levels indicate anemia)
Cystatin C alone or in combination with creatinine values increases the accuracy of the estimated GFR and its
association with the risk of death and ESRD. This is based on a metaanalysis of 11 general population and 5 cohort studies that included over 92,000 patients(23)
Ultrasound  if small, echogenic kidneys are observed bilaterally, this finding supports the diagnosis of CKD
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of herbal, behavioral, or other alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, medical marijuana) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has previously received exercise therapy and what specific program was followed. What education has patient already received about management of CKD?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms such as pain or fatigue at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Common in patients with CKD. Document number of wakings/night -Insomnia might be present in later stages of CKD as well as restless leg syndrome(27)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could reduce the ability to exercise and/ or symptoms that might indicate referral to physician (e.g., dizziness, shortness of breath, headache, swelling of ankles, lack of energy) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the use of any supplemental oxygen or the need for any assistance with ventilation

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior exercise prescription or exercise therapy for chronic conditions?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Any history of heart disease, hypertension, stroke, diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, or osteoporosis? Are diabetes and hypertension wellcontrolled? In a large United Kingdom cohort study of 868,616 patients from the United Kingdom Diabetes Audit, renal dysfunction was diagnosed in 42.3% and 32.4% of patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes, respectively(19)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of all prescribed and OTC medications and herbal remedies that are being taken. If applicable, any use of illegal drugs?
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask about symptoms related to physical exertion

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work or participate in fitness activities? Note the patient’s baseline level of PA. Is the patient a smoker?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: If applicableAsk about family situation, employment status, and working conditions that might increase stress/anxiety

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate ›Relevant tests and measures:  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Determine height, weight, and BMI. Document whether the patient is overweight or obese as indicated by BMI
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Is an assistive device being used for ambulation or to allow greater independence in ADLs?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance reactions to clear for specific modes of exercise. Functional Reach Test or Berg Balance Test, as indicated
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Based on data collected from 651,749 United States veterans with CKD, the optimal BP in patients with CKD is

130159/7089  mmHg. Patients with these values had the lowest adjusted mortality rates and those in whom both systolic BP and diastolic BP were concomitantly very high or very low had the highest mortality rates(22)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Confirm that peripheral pulses are palpable in all limbs
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Check for normalcy in gross movement during transfers and functional tasks using the upper extremities (e.g., reaching, pulling, pushing, holding) and lower extremities (steps, squatting, kneeling, kicking, etc.). Timed Up and Go (TUG) test for functional mobility, FIM for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess ambulatory function, including synchrony of limb movements and posture, for suitability of a walking exercise program. Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) for gait safety, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manually scan strength in functional tasks (e.g., pushing, pulling, sittingup, squatting). Assess handgrip strength with a hand dynamometer
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess for functional ROM in all extremities during the prescribed exerciseAssess deep tendon reflexesScan dermatomes. Assess proprioception if indicated by poor balance
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –Graded exercise testing on a treadmill or cycle ergometer -In compliance with medical guidelines, assess HR, BP, and RPE responses and monitor for adverse signs/symptoms.(2) Do not use any percentage of the age-predicted  maximal HR as a target in progressive exercise testing because the maximal-achievable  HR might be lower than predicted

contraindications precautions: Symptoms of cardiac and respiratory discomfort during ADLs
Fear of exercise and lack of confidence

If none of the above is present, experts in the United Kingdom recommend that an initial evaluation should include a referral to a community-supported  PA program and a written, self-managed  PA and exercise plan to follow until next reevaluation
systolic BP exceeds 250 mmHg or diastolic BP exceeds 115 mmHg
systolic BP falls unexpectedly more than 10 mmHg
the patient reports chest discomfort, lightheadedness, or dyspnea suggestive of cardiac insufficiency
other: Patients with CKD are at increased risk for fracture due to severe hyperparathyroidism, osteoporosis, osteomalacia, adynamic bone disease, and post-transplantation  syndrome. The risk of hip and vertebral fractures increases with the severity of CKD, especially ESRD(20)
Patients with CKD might be on fluid restrictions, which might affect their ability to exercise, especially if they perspire heavily. Consult with physician or dietician if there are concerns
Tailor the exercise prescription to match the patient’s functional ability, symptoms, and cardiorespiratory responses to exercise testing
Ensure close supervision with instruction during the initial phase of exercise therapy and functional training sessions
Certain populations might require continuing structured and supervised exercise if they have at least one of the following:(29)
Hypertension is common in patients with CKD. Monitor BP on a regular basis during PA. According to standard exercise guidelines,(2) exercise should be terminated if
Resting BP higher than 180/110 mmHg is an absolute contraindication and BP higher than 160/100 mmHg is a relative contraindication to performing resistance exercise(2)
Provide the patient with a thorough orientation to using therapeutic exercise equipment and with adequate warm-up  time to help reduce apprehension about exercise
In addition to monitoring HR and BP for appropriate responses, use the patient’s RPE and reported symptoms to make the exercise tolerable for either aerobic or resistance training(3)

Extend the cooldown period and avoid having the patient stop suddenly after exercise, because this might cause a precipitous fall in systolic BP due to venous pooling (i.e., orthostatic hypotension with possibly syncope)
Clinicians should follow the exercise guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician
Electrotherapeutic modalities are indicated for coexisting musculoskeletal conditions when prescribed by the referring physician or if, in clinician’s judgment, the benefit outweighs any risk
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment regarding the use of modalities

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CKD/generalized pain and paresthesias. Deficits in physical functioning can be associated with muscle weakness ROM limitations reduced endurance disturbed balance difficulty in ambulation limitations in ADLsCardiovascular disease (e.g., coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, stroke, heart failure, pericarditis), anemia, coagulopathy, osteoporosis, diabetes mellitus, electrolyte abnormalities, metabolic syndrome, neuromuscular irritability, decreased libido and erectile dysfunction, anovulation
prognosis: Patients with CKD are more likely to have a major cardiovascular event than to progress to ESRD. These patients have a worse prognosis with higher mortality rates following a-myocardial infarction than patients without CKD. Furthermore, patients with CKD are at higher risk for recurrent myocardial infarction, heart failure, and sudden cardiac death(24)
Untreated CKD inevitably progresses to ESRD, resulting in the need for dialysis or transplantation

Authors of a population-based  cohort study in South Korea involving 1,473 non-dialysis-dependent  patients with CKD found an increased mortality rate (134 per 1,000 persons) compared to the age-matched healthy control group (30 per 1,000 persons)(4)

Serial measurements of handgrip strength (HGS) are used to assess muscle function related to nutritional status in patients with CKD. Loss of HGS is associated with poor renal outcomes (e.g.,higher levels of inflammation, fluid overload, low pre-dialysis  sodium levels, and protein energy wasting).(5) Low pre-dialysis  sodium levels are associated with malnutrition and mortality
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physician for management of medical symptoms related to CKD Clinical exercise testing laboratory for direct measurement of VO 2 peak Nutritionist for dietary management and advice on weight management –The following recommendations are based on the Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) 2012 clinical practice guidelines(26) -Protein intake should be 0.8g/kg/day in all adults and GFR < 30 ml/min/1.73m2. High-protein  diets should be avoided in patients with CKD -Hemoglobin A1c should be ≤ 7% to prevent or delay the progression of microvascular complications associated with diabetes and CKD. For those with comorbidities or limited life expectancy and risk for hypoglycemia, hemoglobin A1c can be > 7% -Sodium intake should be < 2g per day unless contraindicated Occupational therapist for limitations in ADLs Psychiatrist/psychologist for stress/anxiety disorder –In a review of the literature, Greek researchers reported that patients with CKD present with long-term  psychological difficulties related to maintaining their employment, social life, financial stability, and diet constraints(21)
other considerations: Educate patients to be physically active on most days of the week, ideally for a total of 30 minutes per day, at an exertion level that is easily tolerated(11)

Higher BMI and obesity are associated with more rapid disease progression in patients with CKD.Lifestyle interventions including reduction in body fat through caloric restriction, increasing activity levels, and nutritional education may reduce or ameliorate CDK progression(6)

Authors of a mini-meta-analysis  looking at GFR during the holy month of Ramadan (alternating abstinence and feasting periods) demonstrated that GFR did not significantly change during this period, suggesting that patients with CKD can safely fast during Ramadan(30)

Based on a United States–based  qualitative study, the treatment burden on patients with CKD can improve by addressing four components: eliciting family and social support, diet modification, healthy lifestyle and medication compliance, and learning to monitor CKD and comorbidities(33)
treatment summary: Exercise/PA/lifestyle modifications –Researchers investigating the perspective of the patient with CKD on exercise and PA identified both barriers to exercise and motivating factors(31) -Barriers: physical (fatigue, non-specific, comorbidities), psychological (reduced motivation, anxiety) and social (time and cost) -Motivators: support, education, and gentle exercise -Preferred exercise was walking, and authors suggested that walking combined with an educational manual has the potential to encourage patients with CKD to be more active -Based on questionnaires (Leisure Time Questionnaire and free text comments on preferred exercise) given to 1,357 pre-dialysis  patients at 3 clinics in the United Kingdom -1,104 or 81.4% of the pre-dialysis  patients were labeled inactive –Exercise has been shown to improve efficiency of muscle mitochondrial oxidative metabolism, which is strongly correlated with muscle power(12) –Researchers in Pakistan investigated the effectiveness of high-intensity  aerobic resistance exercise, including interval and circuit training, on improving exercise capacity in patients with CDK(7) -82 patients ages 36–71  years with CKD stages 2–5 were recruited to participate in the study and assigned to either the interval group (N = 41) or the circuit group (N = 41) -Each group exercised 3x/week for a duration of 50–55 minutes for 8 weeks (2 weeks supervised followed by 6 weeks at home). Borg’s RPE scale was used to monitor and modulate exercise intensity, frequency, and duration during each session. Vital signs (pulse rate and BP) and 6MWT were assessed at baseline and post intervention -Exercise protocol for the interval group consisted of 10-minute  warm-up  of general stretching, followed by 30–35 minutes of aerobic and resistive training (usinga stationary bike only) followed by 10-minute cooldown. The circuit training group performed the same 10-minute  stretch warm-up,  followed by 30–35 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise (cycling, stair-stepping,  walking,and light weights) without rest periods, followed by 10 minutes of cooldown -Both groups demonstrated significant improvements in pulse rate and performance on the 6MWT. Authors concluded that this model of combined supervised and home-based  exercise training was an effective way to improve exercise capacity in patients with CKD –Improved biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress with training suggest that both endurance and strength training exercises improve muscle function and strength(13) -59 patients (40 men and 19 women) undergoing maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) and 22 (17 men and 5 women) normal controls (CTL),with a mean age of 42 for the MHD and 41 for the CTL,were enrolled in the study -Subjects were randomly assigned to one of 5 groups: 1) CTL (N = 22), 2) MHD with no training (NT; N = 15), 3) MHD with endurance training (ET; N = 13), 4) MHD with strength training (ST; N = 17) and 5) MHD with combination of strength and endurance training (EST; N = 14) -Participants performed supervised exercise 3 x/weekfor 21 weeks, with an initial duration of 20 minutesper session progressed to 40 minutes by week 8 with advancement in work intensity as tolerated -Skeletal muscle biopsies of the right vastus lateralis (VL) muscle wereobtained at baseline and post intervention  -Post intervention, compared to baseline the capillary density of the VL muscle increased significantly in both the EST and ET groups but not in the ST group. Researchers concluded that performance of ET and EST improves oxidative capacity and muscle power of MHD patients –A routine walking program can enhance immune function and reduce inflammation(14) -Based on a small non-randomized  study involving 15 dialysis-dependent  patients with CKD -Patients performed home-based  treadmill walking at 1% grade for 30 minutes at a speed that elicited a RPE 12–14,  5 days/week for 6 months -All patients completed an exercise test (recording of HR response to exercise) and blood samples of inflammatory markers were obtained at rest (pre-exercise),  immediately after exercise,and 1 hour after exercise at baseline and 6 months –Researchers conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to evaluate the effects of exercise training on markers of inflammation and nutrition in non-dialysis-dependent  (NDD) patients with CKD(15) -16 RCTs (N = 724 patients) through October 2020 were included -The overall effect of exercise on BMI, waist circumference, and levels of inflammation was statistically significant -Researchers concluded that exercise training may improve inflammatory status in NDD-CKD  patients and enhance weight loss in obese adult CKD patients –Exercise may improve depression and anxiety in patients with CKD(34) -Based on the results of a systematic review and meta-analysis  including 8 RCTspublished through February 2020 -Results showed that participants in exercise programs experienced decreased self-reported  levels of depression and anxiety –Occupational therapy provided for hospitalized CKD patients improves functional capacity and promotes independence through the provision of education and emotional support(35) –Compared to aerobic exercise only, exercise programs combining aerobic and resistive training performed for more than 6 months result in greater improvements in exercise capacity (VO2) (25) –The BASES expert statement suggested using the FITT (frequency, intensity, time, type) principle when prescribing exercise for patients with CKD(29) –Primary care physicians need to be educated on the benefits of exercise training and guidelines for training for patients with CKD(32) . desired outcomes: Improved strength–MMT, ability to do functional tasks
Improved aerobic endurance–Cycle or treadmill graded exercise testing, VO2peak, 6MWT
Improved balance–Berg Balance Scale or Functional Reach Test
Improved functional exercise capacity in daily activities–TUG test, STS60, 6MWT
Improved QOL–Health Status Questionnaire Short Form (SF-36,  physical functioning scale and physical composite scale)

maintenance or prevention: In a 2015 review, the authors recommended that prescription of exercise interventions should become part of the standard nephrological care for patients with CKD(30) Based on the fact that PA, cardiorespiratory fitness, and muscle function are low in patients with CKD and that a sedentary lifestyle has been associated with an increased risk of mortality and morbidity

An expert statement issued by researchers in the United Kingdom (BASES) also states that renal medicine services need to evolve to incorporate exercise rehabilitation as part of a comprehensive and integrated renal care package, including “exercise on prescription”(29)
Early diagnosis can prevent or slow progression of complications such as cardiovascular compromise

American Academy of Physicians clinical guidelines and United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations on screening areas follows:(17) There is insufficient evidence to assess the balance of benefits and harm of routine screening for CKD in asymptomatic adults. Patients with or without diabetes who are currently taking an ACE inhibitor or an ARB should not be tested routinely for proteinuria

KDIGO updated clinical practice guidelines for the management of blood pressure in CKDin 2021 based on a systematic review of the literature(26) BP control and the reduction of proteinuria are critical in preventing CKD progression(24) Systolic blood pressure of < 120 mmHg for non-dialysis-dependent CDK patients is recommended(30) Lifestyle modifications that include reducing sodium intake to < 2g per day, maintaining a healthy BMI of 20 to 25 kg/ m2, smoking cessation, and exercising for 30 minutes 5 times per week, in conjunction with good diabetes control (target hemoglobin A1c level of 7%), are all associated with reducing proteinuria and slowing the progression of CKD(24,26)
Continue prescribed exercise and functional training through independent home program
Weight reduction and control, as indicated
Lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking, alcohol intake), as appropriate
Patients are at high risk for fractures and should be educated on fall prevention and advised to participate in regular exercise and to avoid smoking and alcohol(19)
